channel.title: Posts on Yale Undergraduate Quantum Computing
channel.description: Recent content in Posts on Yale Undergraduate Quantum Computing

item.title: Allen Mi (Board 2021-22: Co-President)
item.description: Co-President (2021-22)

item.title: Ayelet Kalfus (Board 2021-22: Co-President)
item.description: Co-President (2021-22) Ayelet Kalfus is a sophomore at Yale majoring in physics. Fascinated by quantum computers’ potential to revolutionize our world, Ayelet is excited by the opportunity to join a nascent field. Originally from NYC, Ayelet loves exploring new cities, art, film, and writing.

item.title: Aidan Evans (Board 2021-22: Director of Projects)
item.description: Director of Projects (2021-22) Computer Science and Philosophy, Class of 2023 Website, LinkedIn, Github Aidan Evans is a current undergraduate student at Yale University double majoring in Computer Science (BS/MS) and Philosophy (BA). He is extremely passionate about these fields – especially in the areas of quantum computation, logic, computability, and complexity theory.

item.title: Opportunities Bulletin
item.description: Here is a collection of opportunities spanning research projects, internships, hackathons, and more! This list is updated weekly. Week of Apr 18, 2021 IBM Quantum Community Partnerships Intern role Join IBM Quantum and help their team strengthen the quantum community from the first introduction to quantum through to quantum computing research and development. IBM Quantum Community Partnership Interns will have the opportunity to work on projects related to blogging, scientific and technical writing, quantum education, outreach, community events, and open-source software, among other areas of focus.

item.title: Argyris Giannisis Manes (Board 2021-22: Quantum Coalition Liaison)
item.description: Quantum Coalition Liaison (2021-22)

item.title: Ben McDonough (Board 2021-22: QC Hack Director)
item.description: QC Hack Director (2021-22) Ben is a junior in the class of 2024. Ben is a physics major but loves math and computer science as well, and he feels drawn to the interdisciplinary nature of the quantum community. He believes that studying quantum information is a method for investigating fundamental properties of nature. He conducted research under Professor Girvin during the summer of ‘21 into quantum error correction, and he would love to talk to you about it.

item.title: Brandon Yee (Board 2021-22: Head of Web Development)
item.description: Head of Web Development (2021-22)

item.title: Garrek Chan (Board 2021-22: Social Chair)
item.description: Social Chair (2021-22) Garrek is freshman in Saybrook College from San Diego, CA. He is excited about the potential applications of quantum especially as it relates to genome assembly and DNA sequencing. Outside of YUQC, Garrek plays on the Yale Club Soccer Team. He enjoys running, nature photography, and cooking.

item.title: Jean Wang (Board 2021-22: Director of Invited Talks)
item.description: Director of Invited Talks (2021-22)

item.title: Katerina Kargioti (Board 2021-22: Director of Partnerships)
item.description: Director of Partnerships (2021-22)

item.title: Nikhil Harle (Board 2021-22: Director of Resources)
item.description: Director of Resources (2021-22) Nikhil is a junior majoring in intensive physics. His research interests include the implementation of topological QC on current NISQ devices and vertex frustration in artificial spin ice. Nikhil is YuQC’s Director of Resources, and directed the inaugural QC Hack. Apart from physics, you can find him singing opera, watching soccer, and doing crossword puzzles.

item.title: Richard Li (Board 2021-22: Technical Director of QC Hack)
item.description: Technical Director of QC Hack (2021-22) Richard is a senior studying Physics and is the technical director of QCHack. He believes that quantum computing has the potential to tackle some of the most pressing challenges of our time. He is very excited to learn from everybody, and to have a great time hanging out with all members of YuQC! In his free time, he likes to play soccer, watch stuff on Youtube, and learn the guitar.

item.title: Seun Omonije (Board 2021-22: CS Liaison)
item.description: CS Liaison (2021-22) Director of Open Source Projects (2020-21) Computer Science, Class of 2022 LinkedIn | Github Bio: Oluseun (Seun) Omonije ‘22 is a Computer Science major from Dallas, TX in Silliman College. A two-time Google Intern, Seun got started in quantum during the summer of 2020 while attending a Google AI Quantum event. Since then, he spent a semester as a research assistant for Prof. Lin Zhong’s Efficient Computing Lab, helping to solve problems pertaining to quantum error correction, specifically optimizations to the control system between QEC decoders and physical quantum system, as well as the algorithms running within these control systems.

item.title: Suba Ramesh (Board 2021-22: Treasurer)
item.description: Treasurer (2021-22)

item.title: Wyatt Kremer (Board 2021-22: QC Hack Director of Partnerships)
item.description: QC Hack Director of Partnerships (2021-22) Intensive Physics, Class of 2024 Wyatt Kremer is a sophomore Intensive Physics major with broad interests in AMO and quantum many-body systems. He is super excited to be joining the YuQC board and to foster the connection between industry and academia as the director of partnerships alongside the Hackathon team. Beyond physics, Wyatt loves to explore the wonders of Middle Egyptian hieroglyphic and spend time with his friends.

item.title: Jeffrey Gong (Project Leader 2021-22: IBM Qiskit Study Group
item.description: Jeffrey is a Freshman in Saybrook College prospectively majoring in Computer Science and Mathematics, and possibly also Applied Physics. This year, he is the project leader for the IBM Qiskit study group and is doing research on magic state distillation with Professor Yongshan Ding in the Quantum Computer Systems group. Outside of quantum, Jeffrey loves to pretend like he’s an amateur film critic, DJ for his friends, and longboard down scary hills.

item.title: Lucas Huang (Project Leader 2021-22: Quantum Cryptography Study Group
item.description: Lucas is a first-year student majoring in Computer Science and Mathematics with a passion in cybersecurity, specializing in cryptography, which eventually led him to develop an interest in quantum cryptography and all things quantum.

item.title: Ali Hafez
item.description: Ali is a first-year student in Morse College, planning to major in Computer Science and likely double major. He is interested in technology, physics, mathematics, and graphics, and particularly enthused to explore the intersection between quantum computing and graphics.

item.title: Connor Totilas
item.description: Connor Totilas is currently a sophomore in Benjamin Franklin College originally from Orlando, FL. He intends to major in Computer Science and Mathematics with a certificate in Statistics and Data Science. In his spare time he enjoys playing the French Horn and is a member of the Yale Symphony Orchestra. Connor has a particular interest in the application of artificial intelligence with quantum computers and an interest in quantum cryptography.

item.title: Derek Dong
item.description: Derek is a first-year planning to major in math. He is interested in quantum error correction and potential applications of quantum computing in machine learning. He has a strong background in mathematics and computer science.

item.title: Michael Sacks
item.description: Physics, Class of 2024

item.title: Rome Thorstenson
item.description: Rome Thorstenson is a first year in Branford from Chicago, IL. In terms of a major, he’s somewhere between Computer Science and Physics and Philosophy. Other passions include software development, entrepreneurship, soccer, and reading and writing fiction.

item.title: Sam Antonyan
item.description: Sam is a freshman at Yale University majoring in Computer Science and Mathematics. He is also planning to get a certificate in Statistics and Data Science. Sam became interested in quantum computing in his freshman year, and he is excited to explore the quantum world even more, with its amazing applications in real life.

item.title: Vedanth Iyer
item.description: Vedanth is a first year in Berkeley College studying Computer Science and Mathematics. He has a deep interest in both energy and quantum computing. In high school, Vedanth conducted research on batteries using computational quantum mechanics which sparked his interest for quantum computing. After college, he hopes to pursue grad school or take on a research position at a tech company. Outside of his academic interests, Vedanth enjoys playing basketball, soccer, and chess, and is a competitive speedcuber (Rubik’s cube speed solver).

item.title: Will Sun
item.description: Will is a senior physics major with a strong interest in machine learning and quantum computing. In last year’s QC Hack, Will worked with Richard on drafting, debugging, and displaying a quantum oracle for determining legal positions in the Battleship board game. This culminated in a 2nd place finish among 78 teams, a presentation to the Microsoft Quantum team, and a blog post on the Microsoft Q# Developer Blog. Will is currently conducting his senior research on constructing quantum generative adversarial networks (QGANs) to generate multi-qubit states, hoping to generate more intricate images with significantly reduced parameter sets.

item.title: Quantum Computing Summer School 2022
item.description: Information The 5th edition of the Quantum Computing Summer School at Los Alamos National Laboratory (LANL) is happening this summer. The Quantum Computing Summer School is an immersive 10-week curriculum that includes tutorials from world-leading experts in quantum computation as well as one-on-one mentoring from LANL staff scientists who are conducting cutting-edge quantum computing research. Summer school fellowship recipients will be exposed to the theoretical foundations of quantum computation and will become skilled at programming commercial quantum computers, such as those developed by D-Wave Systems, Rigetti, and IBM.

item.title: How to Prepare for the Quantum Workforce Series
item.description: Information Our advisor Florian Carle is hosting a cool professional development panel about working in quantum startups on Oct 29 at 4 pm! See details below. More information: https://quantuminstitute.yale.edu/resources/how-join-quantum-workforce Link to register: https://yale.zoom.us/webinar/register/WN_iW2BwsRWS4KSZ4C3ugVO-w Other events that might be interesting! Public Talk - Sean Carroll: The Many Worlds of Quantum Mechanics - Tuesday, November 2, 2021 - 5:00pm https://quantuminstitute.yale.edu/event/public-talk-sean-carroll-many-worlds-quantum-mechanics How to Join the Quantum Workforce? – Prepare for Industry - Friday, December 10, 2021 - 4:00pm https://quantuminstitute.

item.title: Recap 2020-21
item.description: tl;dr 30+ active members across disciplines Open Source Projects and Study Groups Quantum Coalition (Hack) & Partnerships & Outreach YuQC Invited Speaker Series Social Hours Resources Yale undergrad Quantum Computing was founded in October of 2020 and, in our first year, we’ve done quite a lot. Let’s take a look back at our productive year! Members As shown through data collected at our interest meeting, YuQC brought together students from across disciplines, school years, and experience levels.

item.title: Speaker Series (Spring 2021)
item.description: Here is a summary and schedule of the YuQC Speaker Series. Information & Recordings Check out this Youtube playlist of all past talk recordings!! Please click here (yale.edu account required) to access zoom links, meeting passwords, and, eventually, recordings for this speaker series. Dr. Zlatko Minev To catch and reverse a quantum jump mid-flight April 21, 7:00PM-8:00PM ET Dr. Minev is a scientist with an applied experimental and theoretical background, focused on quantum computing and fundamental physics.

item.title: Quantum Cryptography
item.description: About We are going through an edX course titled “Quantum Cryptography” to gain knowledge and experience in the field. Once a sufficient amount of fundamental concepts is learned, we will start to implement quantum network protocols for the Quantum Protocol Zoo, an open repository founded by our very own Shraddha Singh. Project Lead: Argyris Giannisis Manes, Yiğit Kılıçoğlu. Team: Sami Alves, Ryan Bose-Roy, Ines Chung-Halpern, Sofia Fausone, Francis Fedora, Argyris Giannisis Manes,

item.title: Quantum Error Correction Study Group
item.description: About We concluded the study group with our last meeting on 8/17/2021! We are looking forward to the next academic year, and look for a future iteration at the next YuQC meeting! This is a study group that was started during the spring semester of 2021, and met weekly through August of the following summer. We would like to thank our graduate mentor Alec Eikbusch for his tremendous support of this group, fielding our questions in-person and over discord, and setting up meetings with postdocs and other graduate students who are actively working in this field.

item.title: YuQC Resources and Knowledge Database
item.description: Please take a look through the following database for resources that will help you learn more about quantum computation and quantum information science. Use the organizational features to sort items by type or by difficult level to suit your specific needs, or search directly for items! YuQC Resource Database To suggest other items to add to our database, please reach out to the Director of Resources: Shoumik Chowdhury. Additionally, PDFs of certain texts may be available upon request — reach out to learn more!

item.title: Quantum Programming API
item.description: About The goal of this project is to provide a quantum programming API that will help people who want to incorporate quantum speed-ups into their classical programs much easier. This project aims to both create the infrastructure to communicate with quantum systems and to create with that same infrastructure. We hope that our efforts in building this can lead to inspiration and further advances with the use of quantum computing in the broader computer science community.

item.title: Quantum Coalition Hackathon
item.description: Attend Please visit quantumcoalition.io to learn more about this exciting virtual hackathon co-hosted by Yale and Stanford, open to everyone, and sponsored by Quantum Computing industry innovators. Registration launches on February 14, 2021! Join the Organizing Committee If you are a YuQC member interested in joining the QC Hack Organizing Committee, please sign up here. Sponsors Coming soon…

item.title: Getting Started
item.description: Please take a moment to explore our site and read this post from our Fall 2020 interest meeting to learn a bit more about our organization. Then, please read through the following onboarding guide for new YuQC members. Sign-Up Please fill out this membership interest form (https://forms.gle/X2k8scLqNkgsvLv1A) to join the Yale Undergrad Quantum Computing group mailing list, Discord and more. Most of our discussion is held over Discord. Join a Project Learn how to join existing projects and even propose new projects here.

item.title: Project Ideas
item.description: Projects: efforts ranging open-source packages to hackathon events to resource development and more! SUBMIT YOUR PROJECT IDEAS: Have an idea for a project? Click here to propose a project! NOTE: Each project requires a corresponding project proposal that can be filled out and submitted later. Click here for the template for the write-up. Join a project team: Want to see what we’re working on? Click here to check out our project spreadsheet.

item.title: Fall 2020 Interest Meeting
item.description: The Fall 2020 interest meeting was held on Nov 22nd, 2020 from 1:00PM to 1:30PM ET. Thanks so much to everyone who could make it. If you were unable to attend the event, absolutely no worries. Please take a moment to view (yale.edu email required) the recording and the slides from the meeting. Summary Over 60+ form submissions, with 30+ interest meeting attendees! Each member is involved with at least one “project”: open-source project, tutorials, hackathon planning outreach, etc.

item.title: Quantum Information Science classes at Yale
item.description: Here is a growing list of Yale classes with applications towards Quantum Information Science. Much more coming soon. Quantum Information Physics 345: Introduction to Quantum Information Processing and Communication, Prof Steven Girvin Who should take it: Anyone with a knowledge of complex numbers and introductory linear algebra. This course presents a very accessible and exciting foray into quantum information science. This is highly recommended to anyone looking to begin their journey with quantum computing, with or without a technical physics background.

item.title: Yale Quantum Institute
item.description: Here is a growing list of interdisciplinary Yale efforts in Quantum Computing under the umbrella of the Yale Quantum Institute. Useful Sites quantuminstitute.yale.edu Yale Quantum Institute Events Institute History Institute Members Join the mailing list! quantum.yale.edu A collection of quantum computing research efforts and labs at Yale looking into topics spanning Physics, Applied Physics, Chemistry, Computer Science, and Engineering. Information about the Quantum Week at Yale. Comprehensive statistics about the Quantum efforts at Yale.

item.title: Open-source Resources
item.description: Here are some resources to help you along with your open source quantum endeavours. QC Open Source Projects Quantum Open Source Foundation Open Source Projects Mentorship Learning Prizes and Funding Projects Unitary Fund Non-profit Microgrants Research projects

item.title: Qiskit
item.description: Qiskit is IBM’s open source quantum computing SDK. There is a vibrant community of open source developers and quantum advocates. Getting Started Join the Qiskit slack! Here are some curated tutorials to get yourself started with Qiskit and the IBM Quantum Experience: Code your first quantum circuit CH 1-3 of Qiskit Textbook Beginner Tutorials Events Stay up to date with Qiskit events. Past events: Hackathons IBM Qiskit Global Summer School Quantum Advocates Apply to become one of ~200 Quantum Advocate across ~30 countries at IBM.

item.title: qtcodes
item.description: Status qtcodes is published on PyPI with tooling to encode, decode and benchmark XXXX/ZZZZ surface code, XZZX surface code, and repetition code! About We are building Encoder and Minimum Weight Perfect Matching Graph Decoder tools for serveral Topological Codes we wish to implement in Qiskit Ignis. Here is the Github repo: https://github.com/yaleqc/qtcodes Here is a link to our project proposal. Team The first iteration of this project was created by members Shantanu Jha ‘21, Henry Liu ‘21, Will Sun ‘22, Shraddha Singh (Grad), and Andy Ding (Grad).

item.title: Qubit by Qubit Initiative
item.description: Apply for paid and volunteer opportunities at the Qubit by Qubit Initiative. Here are some of their current projects: Developing homework, problem sets, or worksheets Developing middle or high school curricula for quantum Developing or editing content for textbook for high school students Developing quantum workshop for K-12 students Being a Teaching Assistant for intro course Teaching quantum workshops to K-12 students Please reach out to member Shoumik Chowdhury ‘21 to learn more!
